docs.lead_paragraph: DVDs tailored to mothers-to-be are an inexpensive way to get in the 30 minutes of daily exercise. Anita Goa, 37, a yoga instructor, tests prenatal workouts while in her seventh month.

headline.main: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Prenatal Workouts

docs.snippet: DVDs tailored to mothers-to-be are an inexpensive way to get in the 30 minutes of daily exercise. Anita Goa, 37, a yoga instructor, tests prenatal workouts while in her seventh month.

docs.lead_paragraph: PREGNANCY is no time to abandon fitness. Sure it's ridiculous (not to mention ill advised) to try to develop steely buns or defined abs in the next nine months. But Kegel exercises may help strengthen pelvic muscles to avoid postpartum incontinence, and modified core workouts can diminish back pain common in pregnancy. ''The key is to modify exercise to the pregnant body,'' said Liz Neporent, who has a master's in exercise physiology. Changes to keep in mind include looser ligaments that can be prone to overstretching, and the shifting center of gravity as the stomach grows.

headline.main: Yum, Pickles, Ice Cream And Fitness
headline.kicker: GEAR TEST WITH ANITA GOA, YOGA INSTRUCTOR

docs.abstract: Anita Goa, yoga instructor in Manhattan who is pregnant, rates five pregnancy workout DVD's; photos (M)
